	<item>
		<title>Travel Quiz: which international city is this?</title>
		<link>http://localhost/whb/?p=226</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 03 Apr 2012 12:49:21 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>themefuse</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/travel-agency/?p=222</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><strong>Los Angeles Times</strong>- Kobe Bryant has received a reported $6.7-million offer from an Italian team, but it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process. The lucrative offers, most of them real, keep rolling in for Kobe Bryant. He got a contract offer this week from an Italian pro team, though it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process.</p>
	              <p>The new offer is for a<strong> reported $6.7 million</strong> from Italian team Virtus Bologna, which begins its season Oct. 9 and would have to come up with a huge insurance policy to land Bryant, not to mention the actual cash to get the 13-time all-star to play on the perennially underachieving team.<br>
	              Bryant, 33, is under contract with the Lakers for three more years and $83.5 million. He has several contract options from the Italian team, according to its general manager, including a shorter per-game deal that would work out to<strong> about $740,000 a game</strong>. All options are non-binding, allowing Bryant to return to the Lakers if the NBA lockout ends.</p>
	<p>Even if Bryant doesn't take the offer seriously, he continues to be a man in motion since having a non-invasive procedure on his bothersome right knee in Germany three months ago.</p>
	<p> He made promotional <u><strong>appearances</strong></u> this summer in the Philippines, China and Singapore, scored 43 points in a pro-am game in Los Angeles, played in a celebrity soccer game in Washington, talked briefly with teams in Turkey and China about playing pro basketball there, and was headed to Europe for more paid appearances next week.</p>
	              <p>The league also canceled 43 exhibition games, three of them involving the Lakers: Oct. 9 vs. Golden State in Fresno, Oct. 12 vs. Atlanta in Ontario and Oct. 15 vs. Atlanta at Staples Center.<br>
	                The Lakers were scheduled to open camp Oct. 4, with their annual media day taking place Oct. 3. Both events have been postponed indefinitely because of the lack of progress in NBA labor negotiations.</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Have a great dinner with our Restaurant Giveaway</title>
		<link>http://localhost/whb/?p=228</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 03 May 2012 12:52:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>themefuse</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/travel-agency/?p=226</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><strong>Los Angeles Times</strong>- Kobe Bryant has received a reported $6.7-million offer from an Italian team, but it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process. The lucrative offers, most of them real, keep rolling in for Kobe Bryant. He got a contract offer this week from an Italian pro team, though it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process.</p>
	              <p>The new offer is for a<strong> reported $6.7 million</strong> from Italian team Virtus Bologna, which begins its season Oct. 9 and would have to come up with a huge insurance policy to land Bryant, not to mention the actual cash to get the 13-time all-star to play on the perennially underachieving team.<br>
	              Bryant, 33, is under contract with the Lakers for three more years and $83.5 million. He has several contract options from the Italian team, according to its general manager, including a shorter per-game deal that would work out to<strong> about $740,000 a game</strong>. All options are non-binding, allowing Bryant to return to the Lakers if the NBA lockout ends.</p>
	<p>Even if Bryant doesn't take the offer seriously, he continues to be a man in motion since having a non-invasive procedure on his bothersome right knee in Germany three months ago.</p>
	<p> He made promotional <u><strong>appearances</strong></u> this summer in the Philippines, China and Singapore, scored 43 points in a pro-am game in Los Angeles, played in a celebrity soccer game in Washington, talked briefly with teams in Turkey and China about playing pro basketball there, and was headed to Europe for more paid appearances next week.</p>
	              <p>The league also canceled 43 exhibition games, three of them involving the Lakers: Oct. 9 vs. Golden State in Fresno, Oct. 12 vs. Atlanta in Ontario and Oct. 15 vs. Atlanta at Staples Center.<br>
	                The Lakers were scheduled to open camp Oct. 4, with their annual media day taking place Oct. 3. Both events have been postponed indefinitely because of the lack of progress in NBA labor negotiations.</p>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Infinity Pool pass - only this weekend</title>
		<link>http://localhost/whb/?p=229</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 20 May 2012 12:53:48 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>themefuse</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/travel-agency/?p=228</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><strong>Los Angeles Times</strong>- Kobe Bryant has received a reported $6.7-million offer from an Italian team, but it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process. The lucrative offers, most of them real, keep rolling in for Kobe Bryant. He got a contract offer this week from an Italian pro team, though it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process.</p>
	              <p>The new offer is for a<strong> reported $6.7 million</strong> from Italian team Virtus Bologna, which begins its season Oct. 9 and would have to come up with a huge insurance policy to land Bryant, not to mention the actual cash to get the 13-time all-star to play on the perennially underachieving team.<br>
	              Bryant, 33, is under contract with the Lakers for three more years and $83.5 million. He has several contract options from the Italian team, according to its general manager, including a shorter per-game deal that would work out to<strong> about $740,000 a game</strong>. All options are non-binding, allowing Bryant to return to the Lakers if the NBA lockout ends.</p>
	<p>Even if Bryant doesn't take the offer seriously, he continues to be a man in motion since having a non-invasive procedure on his bothersome right knee in Germany three months ago.</p>
	<p> He made promotional <u><strong>appearances</strong></u> this summer in the Philippines, China and Singapore, scored 43 points in a pro-am game in Los Angeles, played in a celebrity soccer game in Washington, talked briefly with teams in Turkey and China about playing pro basketball there, and was headed to Europe for more paid appearances next week.</p>
	              <p>The league also canceled 43 exhibition games, three of them involving the Lakers: Oct. 9 vs. Golden State in Fresno, Oct. 12 vs. Atlanta in Ontario and Oct. 15 vs. Atlanta at Staples Center.<br>
	                The Lakers were scheduled to open camp Oct. 4, with their annual media day taking place Oct. 3. Both events have been postponed indefinitely because of the lack of progress in NBA labor negotiations.</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Luxury Style: RITZ-CARLTON Shanghai, Pudong</title>
		<link>http://localhost/whb/?p=230</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 03 Jun 2012 13:04:07 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>themefuse</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/travel-agency/?p=230</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><strong>Los Angeles Times</strong>- Kobe Bryant has received a reported $6.7-million offer from an Italian team, but it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process. The lucrative offers, most of them real, keep rolling in for Kobe Bryant. He got a contract offer this week from an Italian pro team, though it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process.</p>
	              <p>The new offer is for a<strong> reported $6.7 million</strong> from Italian team Virtus Bologna, which begins its season Oct. 9 and would have to come up with a huge insurance policy to land Bryant, not to mention the actual cash to get the 13-time all-star to play on the perennially underachieving team.<br>
	              Bryant, 33, is under contract with the Lakers for three more years and $83.5 million. He has several contract options from the Italian team, according to its general manager, including a shorter per-game deal that would work out to<strong> about $740,000 a game</strong>. All options are non-binding, allowing Bryant to return to the Lakers if the NBA lockout ends.</p>
	<p>Even if Bryant doesn't take the offer seriously, he continues to be a man in motion since having a non-invasive procedure on his bothersome right knee in Germany three months ago.</p>
	<p> He made promotional <u><strong>appearances</strong></u> this summer in the Philippines, China and Singapore, scored 43 points in a pro-am game in Los Angeles, played in a celebrity soccer game in Washington, talked briefly with teams in Turkey and China about playing pro basketball there, and was headed to Europe for more paid appearances next week.</p>
	              <p>The league also canceled 43 exhibition games, three of them involving the Lakers: Oct. 9 vs. Golden State in Fresno, Oct. 12 vs. Atlanta in Ontario and Oct. 15 vs. Atlanta at Staples Center.<br>
	                The Lakers were scheduled to open camp Oct. 4, with their annual media day taking place Oct. 3. Both events have been postponed indefinitely because of the lack of progress in NBA labor negotiations.</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Travel Quiz: which international city is this?</title>
		<link>http://localhost/whb/?p=232</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 20 Jun 2012 13:05:05 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>themefuse</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/travel-agency/?p=232</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><strong>Los Angeles Times</strong>- Kobe Bryant has received a reported $6.7-million offer from an Italian team, but it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process. The lucrative offers, most of them real, keep rolling in for Kobe Bryant. He got a contract offer this week from an Italian pro team, though it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process.</p>
	              <p>The new offer is for a<strong> reported $6.7 million</strong> from Italian team Virtus Bologna, which begins its season Oct. 9 and would have to come up with a huge insurance policy to land Bryant, not to mention the actual cash to get the 13-time all-star to play on the perennially underachieving team.<br>
	              Bryant, 33, is under contract with the Lakers for three more years and $83.5 million. He has several contract options from the Italian team, according to its general manager, including a shorter per-game deal that would work out to<strong> about $740,000 a game</strong>. All options are non-binding, allowing Bryant to return to the Lakers if the NBA lockout ends.</p>
	<p>Even if Bryant doesn't take the offer seriously, he continues to be a man in motion since having a non-invasive procedure on his bothersome right knee in Germany three months ago.</p>
	<p> He made promotional <u><strong>appearances</strong></u> this summer in the Philippines, China and Singapore, scored 43 points in a pro-am game in Los Angeles, played in a celebrity soccer game in Washington, talked briefly with teams in Turkey and China about playing pro basketball there, and was headed to Europe for more paid appearances next week.</p>
	              <p>The league also canceled 43 exhibition games, three of them involving the Lakers: Oct. 9 vs. Golden State in Fresno, Oct. 12 vs. Atlanta in Ontario and Oct. 15 vs. Atlanta at Staples Center.<br>
	                The Lakers were scheduled to open camp Oct. 4, with their annual media day taking place Oct. 3. Both events have been postponed indefinitely because of the lack of progress in NBA labor negotiations.</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Chicago SkyTower - 3 day city-break for only $599</title>
		<link>http://localhost/whb/?p=234</link>
		<pubDate>Tue, 03 Jul 2012 13:06:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>themefuse</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/travel-agency/?p=234</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><strong>Los Angeles Times</strong>- Kobe Bryant has received a reported $6.7-million offer from an Italian team, but it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process. The lucrative offers, most of them real, keep rolling in for Kobe Bryant. He got a contract offer this week from an Italian pro team, though it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process.</p>
	              <p>The new offer is for a<strong> reported $6.7 million</strong> from Italian team Virtus Bologna, which begins its season Oct. 9 and would have to come up with a huge insurance policy to land Bryant, not to mention the actual cash to get the 13-time all-star to play on the perennially underachieving team.<br>
	              Bryant, 33, is under contract with the Lakers for three more years and $83.5 million. He has several contract options from the Italian team, according to its general manager, including a shorter per-game deal that would work out to<strong> about $740,000 a game</strong>. All options are non-binding, allowing Bryant to return to the Lakers if the NBA lockout ends.</p>
	<p>Even if Bryant doesn't take the offer seriously, he continues to be a man in motion since having a non-invasive procedure on his bothersome right knee in Germany three months ago.</p>
	<p> He made promotional <u><strong>appearances</strong></u> this summer in the Philippines, China and Singapore, scored 43 points in a pro-am game in Los Angeles, played in a celebrity soccer game in Washington, talked briefly with teams in Turkey and China about playing pro basketball there, and was headed to Europe for more paid appearances next week.</p>
	              <p>The league also canceled 43 exhibition games, three of them involving the Lakers: Oct. 9 vs. Golden State in Fresno, Oct. 12 vs. Atlanta in Ontario and Oct. 15 vs. Atlanta at Staples Center.<br>
	                The Lakers were scheduled to open camp Oct. 4, with their annual media day taking place Oct. 3. Both events have been postponed indefinitely because of the lack of progress in NBA labor negotiations.</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Have a great dinner with our Restaurant Giveaway</title>
		<link>http://localhost/whb/?p=236</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 23 Jul 2012 13:15:30 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>themefuse</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/travel-agency/?p=236</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><strong>Los Angeles Times</strong>- Kobe Bryant has received a reported $6.7-million offer from an Italian team, but it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process. The lucrative offers, most of them real, keep rolling in for Kobe Bryant. He got a contract offer this week from an Italian pro team, though it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process.</p>
	              <p>The new offer is for a<strong> reported $6.7 million</strong> from Italian team Virtus Bologna, which begins its season Oct. 9 and would have to come up with a huge insurance policy to land Bryant, not to mention the actual cash to get the 13-time all-star to play on the perennially underachieving team.<br>
	              Bryant, 33, is under contract with the Lakers for three more years and $83.5 million. He has several contract options from the Italian team, according to its general manager, including a shorter per-game deal that would work out to<strong> about $740,000 a game</strong>. All options are non-binding, allowing Bryant to return to the Lakers if the NBA lockout ends.</p>
	<p>Even if Bryant doesn't take the offer seriously, he continues to be a man in motion since having a non-invasive procedure on his bothersome right knee in Germany three months ago.</p>
	<p> He made promotional <u><strong>appearances</strong></u> this summer in the Philippines, China and Singapore, scored 43 points in a pro-am game in Los Angeles, played in a celebrity soccer game in Washington, talked briefly with teams in Turkey and China about playing pro basketball there, and was headed to Europe for more paid appearances next week.</p>
	              <p>The league also canceled 43 exhibition games, three of them involving the Lakers: Oct. 9 vs. Golden State in Fresno, Oct. 12 vs. Atlanta in Ontario and Oct. 15 vs. Atlanta at Staples Center.<br>
	                The Lakers were scheduled to open camp Oct. 4, with their annual media day taking place Oct. 3. Both events have been postponed indefinitely because of the lack of progress in NBA labor negotiations.</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Infinity Pool pass - only this weekend</title>
		<link>http://localhost/whb/?p=237</link>
		<pubDate>Fri, 03 Aug 2012 13:16:49 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>themefuse</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/travel-agency/?p=237</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><strong>Los Angeles Times</strong>- Kobe Bryant has received a reported $6.7-million offer from an Italian team, but it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process. The lucrative offers, most of them real, keep rolling in for Kobe Bryant. He got a contract offer this week from an Italian pro team, though it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process.</p>
	              <p>The new offer is for a<strong> reported $6.7 million</strong> from Italian team Virtus Bologna, which begins its season Oct. 9 and would have to come up with a huge insurance policy to land Bryant, not to mention the actual cash to get the 13-time all-star to play on the perennially underachieving team.<br>
	              Bryant, 33, is under contract with the Lakers for three more years and $83.5 million. He has several contract options from the Italian team, according to its general manager, including a shorter per-game deal that would work out to<strong> about $740,000 a game</strong>. All options are non-binding, allowing Bryant to return to the Lakers if the NBA lockout ends.</p>
	<p>Even if Bryant doesn't take the offer seriously, he continues to be a man in motion since having a non-invasive procedure on his bothersome right knee in Germany three months ago.</p>
	<p> He made promotional <u><strong>appearances</strong></u> this summer in the Philippines, China and Singapore, scored 43 points in a pro-am game in Los Angeles, played in a celebrity soccer game in Washington, talked briefly with teams in Turkey and China about playing pro basketball there, and was headed to Europe for more paid appearances next week.</p>
	              <p>The league also canceled 43 exhibition games, three of them involving the Lakers: Oct. 9 vs. Golden State in Fresno, Oct. 12 vs. Atlanta in Ontario and Oct. 15 vs. Atlanta at Staples Center.<br>
	                The Lakers were scheduled to open camp Oct. 4, with their annual media day taking place Oct. 3. Both events have been postponed indefinitely because of the lack of progress in NBA labor negotiations.</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Luxury Style: RITZ-CARLTON Shanghai, Pudong</title>
		<link>http://localhost/whb/?p=242</link>
		<pubDate>Thu, 23 Aug 2012 13:18:19 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>themefuse</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/travel-agency/?p=242</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><strong>Los Angeles Times</strong>- Kobe Bryant has received a reported $6.7-million offer from an Italian team, but it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process. The lucrative offers, most of them real, keep rolling in for Kobe Bryant. He got a contract offer this week from an Italian pro team, though it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process.</p>
	              <p>The new offer is for a<strong> reported $6.7 million</strong> from Italian team Virtus Bologna, which begins its season Oct. 9 and would have to come up with a huge insurance policy to land Bryant, not to mention the actual cash to get the 13-time all-star to play on the perennially underachieving team.<br>
	              Bryant, 33, is under contract with the Lakers for three more years and $83.5 million. He has several contract options from the Italian team, according to its general manager, including a shorter per-game deal that would work out to<strong> about $740,000 a game</strong>. All options are non-binding, allowing Bryant to return to the Lakers if the NBA lockout ends.</p>
	<p>Even if Bryant doesn't take the offer seriously, he continues to be a man in motion since having a non-invasive procedure on his bothersome right knee in Germany three months ago.</p>
	<p> He made promotional <u><strong>appearances</strong></u> this summer in the Philippines, China and Singapore, scored 43 points in a pro-am game in Los Angeles, played in a celebrity soccer game in Washington, talked briefly with teams in Turkey and China about playing pro basketball there, and was headed to Europe for more paid appearances next week.</p>
	              <p>The league also canceled 43 exhibition games, three of them involving the Lakers: Oct. 9 vs. Golden State in Fresno, Oct. 12 vs. Atlanta in Ontario and Oct. 15 vs. Atlanta at Staples Center.<br>
	                The Lakers were scheduled to open camp Oct. 4, with their annual media day taking place Oct. 3. Both events have been postponed indefinitely because of the lack of progress in NBA labor negotiations.</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Travel Quiz: which international city is this?</title>
		<link>http://localhost/whb/?p=244</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 03 Sep 2012 13:19:16 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>themefuse</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/travel-agency/?p=244</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><strong>Los Angeles Times</strong>- Kobe Bryant has received a reported $6.7-million offer from an Italian team, but it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process. The lucrative offers, most of them real, keep rolling in for Kobe Bryant. He got a contract offer this week from an Italian pro team, though it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process.</p>
	              <p>The new offer is for a<strong> reported $6.7 million</strong> from Italian team Virtus Bologna, which begins its season Oct. 9 and would have to come up with a huge insurance policy to land Bryant, not to mention the actual cash to get the 13-time all-star to play on the perennially underachieving team.<br>
	              Bryant, 33, is under contract with the Lakers for three more years and $83.5 million. He has several contract options from the Italian team, according to its general manager, including a shorter per-game deal that would work out to<strong> about $740,000 a game</strong>. All options are non-binding, allowing Bryant to return to the Lakers if the NBA lockout ends.</p>
	<p>Even if Bryant doesn't take the offer seriously, he continues to be a man in motion since having a non-invasive procedure on his bothersome right knee in Germany three months ago.</p>
	<p> He made promotional <u><strong>appearances</strong></u> this summer in the Philippines, China and Singapore, scored 43 points in a pro-am game in Los Angeles, played in a celebrity soccer game in Washington, talked briefly with teams in Turkey and China about playing pro basketball there, and was headed to Europe for more paid appearances next week.</p>
	              <p>The league also canceled 43 exhibition games, three of them involving the Lakers: Oct. 9 vs. Golden State in Fresno, Oct. 12 vs. Atlanta in Ontario and Oct. 15 vs. Atlanta at Staples Center.<br>
	                The Lakers were scheduled to open camp Oct. 4, with their annual media day taking place Oct. 3. Both events have been postponed indefinitely because of the lack of progress in NBA labor negotiations.</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Chicago SkyTower - 3 day city-break for only $599</title>
		<link>http://localhost/whb/?p=246</link>
		<pubDate>Sun, 23 Sep 2012 13:20:26 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>themefuse</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/travel-agency/?p=246</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><strong>Los Angeles Times</strong>- Kobe Bryant has received a reported $6.7-million offer from an Italian team, but it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process. The lucrative offers, most of them real, keep rolling in for Kobe Bryant. He got a contract offer this week from an Italian pro team, though it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process.</p>
	              <p>The new offer is for a<strong> reported $6.7 million</strong> from Italian team Virtus Bologna, which begins its season Oct. 9 and would have to come up with a huge insurance policy to land Bryant, not to mention the actual cash to get the 13-time all-star to play on the perennially underachieving team.<br>
	              Bryant, 33, is under contract with the Lakers for three more years and $83.5 million. He has several contract options from the Italian team, according to its general manager, including a shorter per-game deal that would work out to<strong> about $740,000 a game</strong>. All options are non-binding, allowing Bryant to return to the Lakers if the NBA lockout ends.</p>
	<p>Even if Bryant doesn't take the offer seriously, he continues to be a man in motion since having a non-invasive procedure on his bothersome right knee in Germany three months ago.</p>
	<p> He made promotional <u><strong>appearances</strong></u> this summer in the Philippines, China and Singapore, scored 43 points in a pro-am game in Los Angeles, played in a celebrity soccer game in Washington, talked briefly with teams in Turkey and China about playing pro basketball there, and was headed to Europe for more paid appearances next week.</p>
	              <p>The league also canceled 43 exhibition games, three of them involving the Lakers: Oct. 9 vs. Golden State in Fresno, Oct. 12 vs. Atlanta in Ontario and Oct. 15 vs. Atlanta at Staples Center.<br>
	                The Lakers were scheduled to open camp Oct. 4, with their annual media day taking place Oct. 3. Both events have been postponed indefinitely because of the lack of progress in NBA labor negotiations.</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Have a great dinner with our Restaurant Giveaway</title>
		<link>http://localhost/whb/?p=248</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 03 Oct 2012 13:21:47 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>themefuse</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/travel-agency/?p=248</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><strong>Los Angeles Times</strong>- Kobe Bryant has received a reported $6.7-million offer from an Italian team, but it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process. The lucrative offers, most of them real, keep rolling in for Kobe Bryant. He got a contract offer this week from an Italian pro team, though it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process.</p>
	              <p>The new offer is for a<strong> reported $6.7 million</strong> from Italian team Virtus Bologna, which begins its season Oct. 9 and would have to come up with a huge insurance policy to land Bryant, not to mention the actual cash to get the 13-time all-star to play on the perennially underachieving team.<br>
	              Bryant, 33, is under contract with the Lakers for three more years and $83.5 million. He has several contract options from the Italian team, according to its general manager, including a shorter per-game deal that would work out to<strong> about $740,000 a game</strong>. All options are non-binding, allowing Bryant to return to the Lakers if the NBA lockout ends.</p>
	<p>Even if Bryant doesn't take the offer seriously, he continues to be a man in motion since having a non-invasive procedure on his bothersome right knee in Germany three months ago.</p>
	<p> He made promotional <u><strong>appearances</strong></u> this summer in the Philippines, China and Singapore, scored 43 points in a pro-am game in Los Angeles, played in a celebrity soccer game in Washington, talked briefly with teams in Turkey and China about playing pro basketball there, and was headed to Europe for more paid appearances next week.</p>
	              <p>The league also canceled 43 exhibition games, three of them involving the Lakers: Oct. 9 vs. Golden State in Fresno, Oct. 12 vs. Atlanta in Ontario and Oct. 15 vs. Atlanta at Staples Center.<br>
	                The Lakers were scheduled to open camp Oct. 4, with their annual media day taking place Oct. 3. Both events have been postponed indefinitely because of the lack of progress in NBA labor negotiations.</p>]]></content:encoded>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title>Infinity Pool pass - only this weekend</title>
		<link>http://localhost/whb/?p=250</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 03 Oct 2012 13:22:28 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>themefuse</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/travel-agency/?p=250</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><strong>Los Angeles Times</strong>- Kobe Bryant has received a reported $6.7-million offer from an Italian team, but it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process. The lucrative offers, most of them real, keep rolling in for Kobe Bryant. He got a contract offer this week from an Italian pro team, though it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process.</p>
	              <p>The new offer is for a<strong> reported $6.7 million</strong> from Italian team Virtus Bologna, which begins its season Oct. 9 and would have to come up with a huge insurance policy to land Bryant, not to mention the actual cash to get the 13-time all-star to play on the perennially underachieving team.<br>
	              Bryant, 33, is under contract with the Lakers for three more years and $83.5 million. He has several contract options from the Italian team, according to its general manager, including a shorter per-game deal that would work out to<strong> about $740,000 a game</strong>. All options are non-binding, allowing Bryant to return to the Lakers if the NBA lockout ends.</p>
	<p>Even if Bryant doesn't take the offer seriously, he continues to be a man in motion since having a non-invasive procedure on his bothersome right knee in Germany three months ago.</p>
	<p> He made promotional <u><strong>appearances</strong></u> this summer in the Philippines, China and Singapore, scored 43 points in a pro-am game in Los Angeles, played in a celebrity soccer game in Washington, talked briefly with teams in Turkey and China about playing pro basketball there, and was headed to Europe for more paid appearances next week.</p>
	              <p>The league also canceled 43 exhibition games, three of them involving the Lakers: Oct. 9 vs. Golden State in Fresno, Oct. 12 vs. Atlanta in Ontario and Oct. 15 vs. Atlanta at Staples Center.<br>
	                The Lakers were scheduled to open camp Oct. 4, with their annual media day taking place Oct. 3. Both events have been postponed indefinitely because of the lack of progress in NBA labor negotiations.</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Infinity Pool pass - only this weekend</title>
		<link>http://localhost/whb/?p=279</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 03 Oct 2012 14:12:03 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>themefuse</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/travel-agency/?p=279</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><strong>Los Angeles Times</strong>- Kobe Bryant has received a reported $6.7-million offer from an Italian team, but it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process. The lucrative offers, most of them real, keep rolling in for Kobe Bryant. He got a contract offer this week from an Italian pro team, though it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process.</p>
	              <p>The new offer is for a<strong> reported $6.7 million</strong> from Italian team Virtus Bologna, which begins its season Oct. 9 and would have to come up with a huge insurance policy to land Bryant, not to mention the actual cash to get the 13-time all-star to play on the perennially underachieving team.<br>
	              Bryant, 33, is under contract with the Lakers for three more years and $83.5 million. He has several contract options from the Italian team, according to its general manager, including a shorter per-game deal that would work out to<strong> about $740,000 a game</strong>. All options are non-binding, allowing Bryant to return to the Lakers if the NBA lockout ends.</p>
	<p>Even if Bryant doesn't take the offer seriously, he continues to be a man in motion since having a non-invasive procedure on his bothersome right knee in Germany three months ago.</p>
	<p> He made promotional <u><strong>appearances</strong></u> this summer in the Philippines, China and Singapore, scored 43 points in a pro-am game in Los Angeles, played in a celebrity soccer game in Washington, talked briefly with teams in Turkey and China about playing pro basketball there, and was headed to Europe for more paid appearances next week.</p>
	              <p>The league also canceled 43 exhibition games, three of them involving the Lakers: Oct. 9 vs. Golden State in Fresno, Oct. 12 vs. Atlanta in Ontario and Oct. 15 vs. Atlanta at Staples Center.<br>
	                The Lakers were scheduled to open camp Oct. 4, with their annual media day taking place Oct. 3. Both events have been postponed indefinitely because of the lack of progress in NBA labor negotiations.</p>]]></content:encoded>

		<title>Have a great dinner with our Restaurant Giveaway</title>
		<link>http://localhost/whb/?p=282</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 03 Oct 2012 14:13:12 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>themefuse</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/travel-agency/?p=282</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><strong>Los Angeles Times</strong>- Kobe Bryant has received a reported $6.7-million offer from an Italian team, but it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process. The lucrative offers, most of them real, keep rolling in for Kobe Bryant. He got a contract offer this week from an Italian pro team, though it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process.</p>
	              <p>The new offer is for a<strong> reported $6.7 million</strong> from Italian team Virtus Bologna, which begins its season Oct. 9 and would have to come up with a huge insurance policy to land Bryant, not to mention the actual cash to get the 13-time all-star to play on the perennially underachieving team.<br>
	              Bryant, 33, is under contract with the Lakers for three more years and $83.5 million. He has several contract options from the Italian team, according to its general manager, including a shorter per-game deal that would work out to<strong> about $740,000 a game</strong>. All options are non-binding, allowing Bryant to return to the Lakers if the NBA lockout ends.</p>
	<p>Even if Bryant doesn't take the offer seriously, he continues to be a man in motion since having a non-invasive procedure on his bothersome right knee in Germany three months ago.</p>
	<p> He made promotional <u><strong>appearances</strong></u> this summer in the Philippines, China and Singapore, scored 43 points in a pro-am game in Los Angeles, played in a celebrity soccer game in Washington, talked briefly with teams in Turkey and China about playing pro basketball there, and was headed to Europe for more paid appearances next week.</p>
	              <p>The league also canceled 43 exhibition games, three of them involving the Lakers: Oct. 9 vs. Golden State in Fresno, Oct. 12 vs. Atlanta in Ontario and Oct. 15 vs. Atlanta at Staples Center.<br>
	                The Lakers were scheduled to open camp Oct. 4, with their annual media day taking place Oct. 3. Both events have been postponed indefinitely because of the lack of progress in NBA labor negotiations.</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Chicago SkyTower - 3 day city-break for only $599</title>
		<link>http://localhost/whb/?p=284</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 03 Oct 2012 14:14:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>themefuse</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/travel-agency/?p=284</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><strong>Los Angeles Times</strong>- Kobe Bryant has received a reported $6.7-million offer from an Italian team, but it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process. The lucrative offers, most of them real, keep rolling in for Kobe Bryant. He got a contract offer this week from an Italian pro team, though it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process.</p>
	              <p>The new offer is for a<strong> reported $6.7 million</strong> from Italian team Virtus Bologna, which begins its season Oct. 9 and would have to come up with a huge insurance policy to land Bryant, not to mention the actual cash to get the 13-time all-star to play on the perennially underachieving team.<br>
	              Bryant, 33, is under contract with the Lakers for three more years and $83.5 million. He has several contract options from the Italian team, according to its general manager, including a shorter per-game deal that would work out to<strong> about $740,000 a game</strong>. All options are non-binding, allowing Bryant to return to the Lakers if the NBA lockout ends.</p>
	<p>Even if Bryant doesn't take the offer seriously, he continues to be a man in motion since having a non-invasive procedure on his bothersome right knee in Germany three months ago.</p>
	<p> He made promotional <u><strong>appearances</strong></u> this summer in the Philippines, China and Singapore, scored 43 points in a pro-am game in Los Angeles, played in a celebrity soccer game in Washington, talked briefly with teams in Turkey and China about playing pro basketball there, and was headed to Europe for more paid appearances next week.</p>
	              <p>The league also canceled 43 exhibition games, three of them involving the Lakers: Oct. 9 vs. Golden State in Fresno, Oct. 12 vs. Atlanta in Ontario and Oct. 15 vs. Atlanta at Staples Center.<br>
	                The Lakers were scheduled to open camp Oct. 4, with their annual media day taking place Oct. 3. Both events have been postponed indefinitely because of the lack of progress in NBA labor negotiations.</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Travel Quiz: which international city is this?</title>
		<link>http://localhost/whb/?p=286</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 03 Oct 2012 14:15:14 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>themefuse</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/travel-agency/?p=286</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><strong>Los Angeles Times</strong>- Kobe Bryant has received a reported $6.7-million offer from an Italian team, but it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process. The lucrative offers, most of them real, keep rolling in for Kobe Bryant. He got a contract offer this week from an Italian pro team, though it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process.</p>
	              <p>The new offer is for a<strong> reported $6.7 million</strong> from Italian team Virtus Bologna, which begins its season Oct. 9 and would have to come up with a huge insurance policy to land Bryant, not to mention the actual cash to get the 13-time all-star to play on the perennially underachieving team.<br>
	              Bryant, 33, is under contract with the Lakers for three more years and $83.5 million. He has several contract options from the Italian team, according to its general manager, including a shorter per-game deal that would work out to<strong> about $740,000 a game</strong>. All options are non-binding, allowing Bryant to return to the Lakers if the NBA lockout ends.</p>
	<p>Even if Bryant doesn't take the offer seriously, he continues to be a man in motion since having a non-invasive procedure on his bothersome right knee in Germany three months ago.</p>
	<p> He made promotional <u><strong>appearances</strong></u> this summer in the Philippines, China and Singapore, scored 43 points in a pro-am game in Los Angeles, played in a celebrity soccer game in Washington, talked briefly with teams in Turkey and China about playing pro basketball there, and was headed to Europe for more paid appearances next week.</p>
	              <p>The league also canceled 43 exhibition games, three of them involving the Lakers: Oct. 9 vs. Golden State in Fresno, Oct. 12 vs. Atlanta in Ontario and Oct. 15 vs. Atlanta at Staples Center.<br>
	                The Lakers were scheduled to open camp Oct. 4, with their annual media day taking place Oct. 3. Both events have been postponed indefinitely because of the lack of progress in NBA labor negotiations.</p>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Luxury Style: RITZ-CARLTON Shanghai, Pudong</title>
		<link>http://localhost/whb/?p=288</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 03 Oct 2012 14:16:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>themefuse</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://localhost/travel-agency/?p=288</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<p><strong>Los Angeles Times</strong>- Kobe Bryant has received a reported $6.7-million offer from an Italian team, but it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process. The lucrative offers, most of them real, keep rolling in for Kobe Bryant. He got a contract offer this week from an Italian pro team, though it was far from certain Bryant would play there, according to a person familiar with Bryant's thought process.</p>
	              <p>The new offer is for a<strong> reported $6.7 million</strong> from Italian team Virtus Bologna, which begins its season Oct. 9 and would have to come up with a huge insurance policy to land Bryant, not to mention the actual cash to get the 13-time all-star to play on the perennially underachieving team.<br>
	              Bryant, 33, is under contract with the Lakers for three more years and $83.5 million. He has several contract options from the Italian team, according to its general manager, including a shorter per-game deal that would work out to<strong> about $740,000 a game</strong>. All options are non-binding, allowing Bryant to return to the Lakers if the NBA lockout ends.</p>
	<p>Even if Bryant doesn't take the offer seriously, he continues to be a man in motion since having a non-invasive procedure on his bothersome right knee in Germany three months ago.</p>
	<p> He made promotional <u><strong>appearances</strong></u> this summer in the Philippines, China and Singapore, scored 43 points in a pro-am game in Los Angeles, played in a celebrity soccer game in Washington, talked briefly with teams in Turkey and China about playing pro basketball there, and was headed to Europe for more paid appearances next week.</p>
	              <p>The league also canceled 43 exhibition games, three of them involving the Lakers: Oct. 9 vs. Golden State in Fresno, Oct. 12 vs. Atlanta in Ontario and Oct. 15 vs. Atlanta at Staples Center.<br>
	                The Lakers were scheduled to open camp Oct. 4, with their annual media day taking place Oct. 3. Both events have been postponed indefinitely because of the lack of progress in NBA labor negotiations.</p>]]></content:encoded>
